In physics, there are certain numbers that just are.
They're numbers like the speed of light.
We can't explain why it has that value, but it does.
There are those constants like pi and Planck.
And we take for granted that these numbers would be the same all over the universe.

But now, researchers are reporting that their measurements, another of those physical constants in those measurements known as alpha, the fine-structure constant, well, that constant may not be constant after all.

We've looked with the - two of the largest telescopes in the world, the Keck telescope in Hawaii and the very large telescope, European telescope in Chile, all over the sky at different quasars and investigate galaxies along the lines of sight to those quasars.
And that's what actually allows us to probe the fundamental physics into deep space.
For fun?

It was at that meeting, McGowan alleges, that Weinstein raped her.
She accepted a $100,000 settlement.
He continues to deny sexually assaulting anyone.
And she struggled as Hollywood embraced her attacker.
On one level, ""Citizen Rose"" tells a story of slow vindication.
It shows McGowan's work as an activist last year as news reports revealed allegations of sexual harassment and assault against powerful men.

When McGowan meets with Ronan Farrow, who detailed allegations against Weinstein in The New Yorker, Farrow says allegations that the producer hired people to spy on McGowan seemed preposterous until he reported on them.
(SOUNDBITE OF DOCUMENTARY, ""CITIZEN ROSE"")
You're like the, you know, the guy with the beard and the frazzled hair in a sci-fi movie, you know, saying like, I have the evidence here, doomsday is coming.
And everyone's like, he's crazy.
And then the twist is always, of course, he's completely right.
Yeah.

But ""Citizen Rose"" is also the story of a victim struggling to process trauma, as in this moment, when McGowan is arguing with her mother who resists criticism that she never really talked about her daughter's rape with her.
(SOUNDBITE OF DOCUMENTARY, ""CITIZEN ROSE"")
I don't ask you a lot of things 'cause you spent a lot of years talking [expletive] about me.
And you didn't want to talk on the phone.
And you didn't - you know, it's like, if I asked you a question, it was just like - I can't talk to someone that hates me, is how it felt.
Citizen Rose"" has its flaws.
McGowan seems so focused on telling her own story there isn't much room for others, even when she visits another woman who has accused Weinstein of rape, Italian actress Asia Argento.

Following McGowan's vow to never speak Weinstein's name, the show blurs his name in archival clips, garbles mentions of his name in audio and places a black box over his eyes in pictures, which can feel overly dramatic at times.
And since the series debuted the same day as her memoir, ""Brave,"" there are accusations she's profiting from the Me Too movement.

Still, as Hollywood continues to grapple with allegations of sexual harassment and assault, ""Citizen Rose"" shows a woman trying to fight back by speaking up and encouraging others to find their voices, which is a pretty powerful message.
I'm Eric Deggans.
Today, The New York Times reported on a dossier compiled by the Indian government with gripping details about the Mumbai terror attacks in November.
Details include previously undisclosed transcripts of chilling pep talks and instructions from the terror group's leaders on who to kill and how to inflict maximum damage.
The attacks left at least 160 people dead, and the dossier assembles India's case that the attacks were planned, mounted and directed from Pakistan.
If you have questions about the dossier, our phone number is 800-989-8255; email is talk@npr.org.
You can also join the conversation on our Web site.
That's at npr.org, and click on Talk of the Nation.
Joining us is Somini Sengupta, the New York Times South Asia bureau chief.
Her piece, ""Dossier Gives Details of Mumbai Attacks,"" appeared in today's editions of the paper.
She joins us by phone from India.
Thanks very much for staying up late to speak with us.
Sure.
Thanks.

And you open your piece with the line ""the exchanges are chilling,"" and they include lines like, for example, (Reading) the hostages are of use only as long as you do not come under fire, a supervisor instructed gunman by phone during the Mumbai attacks.
He added, if you are still threatened, then don't saddle yourself with the burden of the hostages.
Immediately kill them.
Yeah, that's right.
They are chilling, they're graphic, and they provide some - a glimpse into how constantly these gunmen were being directed by their handlers, by their supervisors, if you will.
And this was all by cell phone from - it's believed - Pakistan?
This is what the Indians say, that all 10 of these gunmen who carried out the attacks in Mumbai came from Pakistan, and they were on the phone with handlers in Pakistan.
And this is the fundamental thrust of this dossier that India has put together and handed over to Pakistan, officially saying here's the evidence, now act.
They have also provided copies of this dossier to what you describe as friendly governments there in New Delhi - the embassies of friendly governments.
And you quote some unnamed diplomats as describing it as both comprehensive and convincing.
Yes.
They're - they did share it first with diplomats from countries that lost their citizens in the attack and then a handful of other countries.
This is, again, part of the Indian effort to rally international support and to, you know, to rally their allies and other nations to really lean on Pakistan to do something.
Now the Indian demand is for Pakistan to investigate thoroughly, as they say, and help them bring these perpetrators to what they have called Indian justice.
So, specifically, they're asking for the suspects to be handed over, to be tried in the Indian courts.
This is something that the Pakistanis are very, very unlikely to do.

But today, Wednesday, the Pakistani government announced for the first time since these attacks that the lone surviving gunman, a guy that the Indian authorities have in their custody, is a Pakistani citizen.
And so, this is the first time that there has been that kind of formal acknowledgment from Islamabad.
There was also the dismissal of the national security adviser by the prime minister, that's not the president, but the prime minister of Pakistan.
And the language of that dismissal seems evident that this all had something to do with the events in Mumbai.
Right.
I mean, I think the details of what transpired there, you know, will come out in the coming hours and days.
But clearly, this has - what you've seen in the last couple of days - actually, what you've seen in the last couple of weeks from Pakistan is an attempt to show that something is being done.

And remember, there's been a great deal of lobbying by the United States on both sides - on both capitals - in Islamabad and in New Delhi - in Islamabad, to act, to do something and in Delhi, exactly the opposite - not to act, not to do anything, specifically not to take any military action.
And the dossier, as you describe it, does not specify that the Pakistani government was in any way involved.
However, the prime minister there in India said yesterday that the attacks must have had the support of at least some of the official agencies in Pakistan.
